# Using Docker

This is very useful if you have to test multiple versions of tensorflow or pytorch.

0. install an nvidia driver. e.g. `nvidia-driver-410`
1. install `docker-ce`
2. install `nvidia-docker2`
3. use `--runtime=nvidia` option every time for your docker command:
```{sh, eval=FALSE}
$ docker run -it --rm --runtime=nvidia tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-gpu-py3-jupyter /bin/bash

root@7cd9e7919325:/workspace# 
root@7cd9e7919325:/workspace# python
Python 3.6.5 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Apr 29 2018, 16:14:56) 
[GCC 7.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import torch
>>> torch.cuda.is_available()
True
>>> 
```

* if you need to use `pytorch 0.3.0` with `cuda 9.0`, then follow two steps below.

(1) do the following to install `pytorch`:
```
$ docker pull pytorch/pytorch:0.4-cuda9-cudnn7-devel
$ docker run -it --rm --runtime=nvidia pytorch/pytorch:0.4-cuda9-cudnn7-devel

root@cd9ff:/workspace# nvcc --version
Copyright (c) 2005-2017 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Fri_Sep__1_21:08:03_CDT_2017
Cuda compilation tools, release 9.0, V9.0.176

root@cd9ff:/workspace# conda install pytorch=0.3.0 torchvision=0.2.0 cuda90 -c pytorch
```
```
root@7cd9ff:/workspace# python
Python 3.6.8 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Dec 30 2018, 01:22:34) 
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import torch
>>> torch.cuda.is_available()
True
>>> torch.__version__
'0.3.0.post4'
>>> 
```
(2) save the image of the docker container in another terminal
```
$ docker container ps
$ docker commit <container id> pytorch/pytorch:0.3-cuda9-cudnn7-devel-yndk
```
